infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer

    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate
extends TransferEntropyCommon
implements TransferEntropyCalculator

    Computes the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two uniivariate double[] time-series of observations using box-kernel estimation. For details on box-kernel estimation, see Kantz and Schreiber (below).

    TE was defined by Schreiber (below). This estimator is realised here by extending TransferEntropyCommon.

    ***** This implementation is simple in terms of using separate kernel estimators for each probability calculation required. The main TE box-kernel class, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernel is significantly more efficient.

    Since this is not our main TE box-kernel class, the javadocs are not necessarily well-maintained either ... TODO Update javadocs here

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculator, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to #TransferEntropyCalculatorKernel().
    • Further properties are available, see setProperty(String, String);
    • An additional initialise(int, double) option;
    • Additional utility methods for computing other information-theoretic values are available here (e.g. computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection()) which can be called after all observations are supplied.

    TODO Implement dynamic correlation exclusion with multiple observation sets. (see the way this is done in Plain calculator).

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservationsWithCorrection()
                                                       throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the average Transfer Entropy for the previously supplied observations, using the Grassberger correction for the point count k: log_e(k) ~= digamma(k).

        Kaiser and Schreiber, Physica D 166 (2002) pp. 43-62 suggest (on p. 57) that for the TE though the adverse correction of the bias correction is worse than the correction itself (because the probabilities being multiplied/divided are not independent), so recommend not to use this method.

        It is implemented here for testing purposes only.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Computes the local transfer entropies for the previous supplied observations. Where more than one time series has been added, the array contains the local values for each tuple in the order in which they were added. If there was only a single time series added, the array contains k zero values before the local values. (This means the length of the return array is the same as the length of the input time series).
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local TE values. If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then this time-series will have zero entries until the source and destination embedding vectors are defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] source,
                                             double[] destination)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Comptues local transfer entropies for the given observations, using the previously supplied observations to compute the PDFs. I don't think it's such a good idea to do this for continuous variables (e.g. where one can get kernel estimates for probabilities of zero now) but I've implemented it anyway. I guess getting kernel estimates of zero here is no different than what can occur with dynamic correlation exclusion.
        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source -
        destination -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the significance of obtaining the given average TE from the given observations This is as per Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128. Basically, we shuffle the source observations against the destination tuples. This keeps the marginal PDFs the same (including the entropy rate of the destination) but destroys any correlation between the source and state change of the destination.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of new orderings of the source values to compare against
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        As per computeSignificance() but supplies the re-orderings of the observations of the source variables.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - first index is permutation number, i.e. newOrderings[i] is an array of 1 permutation of 0..n-1, where there were n observations.
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."
